That's a great attitude! It's always a good idea to get a professional opinion, especially when it comes to your eye health. The optometrist can assess your eyes and provide personalized recommendations for correcting any vision issues you may have.

Blue light blocking glasses are a great consideration, especially if you spend a lot of time in front of screens. The optometrist can help you determine if blue light blocking glasses would be beneficial for you and recommend the best type of lenses or coatings for your specific needs.

Remember to ask the optometrist about blue light blocking glasses during your appointment. They can help you understand the different types of blue light blocking technology available, such as:

1. **Blue light blocking coatings**: These can be applied to your prescription lenses to block blue light.
2. **Blue light blocking lenses**: Some lenses are specifically designed to block blue light, and can be prescribed for people who spend a lot of time in front of screens.
3. **Blue light blocking glasses with a prescription**: If you need corrective lenses, you can get blue light blocking glasses with a prescription to correct your vision and block blue light.

The optometrist can also help you understand the benefits and limitations of blue light blocking glasses, as well as any potential interactions with other eye conditions or medications.

Don't hesitate to ask questions and discuss your concerns with the optometrist. They're there to help you make informed decisions about your eye health and provide personalized recommendations to meet your needs.

I hope your appointment goes smoothly, and you get the answers and solutions you're looking for!
